Agreed! Most of your logic should be separate from your servlets. However,
paarameter parsing, and mapping the results of calls to implementation
classes into the appropriate scopes necessarily rely on the container's
context. In these cases there are two general approaches:

1) Mock objects
2) In-container testing (Cactus)

Mock objects are lightweigth and clean, but sometimes having the actual
container implementation provide context is vital. I've submitted several
bugs to my container's author that I was able to verify with Cactus tests.

You can find more info on the different ways to test server-side code at:
http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus/mockobjects.html

I find it's a good idea to separate the servlet
implementation code into a different class from the
servelet container.  The servlet class is usually very
small - parameter parsing and dispatching to the
implementation class -- no HTML generation or decision
logic.  In this way, you can write
unit tests on the implementation class and and run
tests on 99% of the code without all the weight of
having a web server running.  In this manner, servlet
testing becomes very easy.

Thanks,
David Jared
